displaytitle: Statuette of a winged mythological figure
creditline: Museum purchase, gift of Alastair B. Martin, Class of 1938

titles.title: Statuette of a winged mythological figure

texts.textentryhtml: There are many winged goddesses and demons depicted in Etruscan art. While we cannot be sure of the identity of this female figure, her wings mark her as a supernatural and possibly even divine being. She wears pointed shoes, a chiton (a tunic fastened at the shoulder), a mantle over her right shoulder, and a crown on her head. With her left hand she holds up her drapery, while with her right hand she held out a now-missing object, possibly a phiale, a shallow dish used to pour out ritual liquid offerings, an example of which is displayed nearby.
Museum purchase from Mathias Komor, New York, in 1976.

geography.displaygeography: Place made: Europe, Italy, Chiusi, Etruria (central Italy)

caption: Etruscan, Classical Period (ca. 480–323 BCE), Chiusi, Etruria (central Italy), Italy, ca. 450–425 BCE, Statuette of a winged mythological figure. Cast bronze; 16.5 x 5.2 x 4.4 cm. Museum purchase, gift of Alastair B. Martin, Class of 1938 (y1976-24)
